Wanderlog staff
Updated • updatedJun 26, 2025
Many of us are foodies on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to eat at the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like Quinary, COA, and The Aubrey and more, get ready to experience the best flavors around Hong Kong.
Why trust us
We scoured through the internet and read through 39 reputable sites and blogs like Time Out and Condé Nast Traveler. We gathered all the results in one place and ranked them by how many times they were mentioned so you know you're getting the best of the best. Just look for the "mentioned by" tags on each place like these:

1Quinary

Slide 1 of 5
4.6
(888)
•
Mentioned on 
+16 other lists 
$$$$expensive
Cocktail bar
Quinary is a renowned cocktail bar in Hong Kong that has been a prominent player in the city's cocktail scene since its establishment in 2012. The founder, Antonio Lai, is recognized as a pioneer in local mixology. The bar is known for its innovative and trendsetting cocktails, such as the signature Earl Grey Caviar Martini, which has become a classic favorite.
Slide 1 of 8
We found this place in a book I got in a cool shop in MN a few months back. It is the 150 bars you have to visit before you die. It mentions the earl grey martini and a walk in the clouds. A drink you have to get as the place only makes 10 a day. As we missed put on the walk in the clouds we did have 2 signature drinks from here. The earl grey and the lemon merengue pie. Both we some of the coolest drinks I have ever seen. You had to bite bubbles or you would get drink up your nose...seriously. but if you did it right it taste just like a blast of the pie or tea...it was bonkers. We also got a drink menu you can buy them and an explanation of the drinks. If you are in this city please please please check this place out the vibe and the area will set the tone for a great evening. I forget the young lady who helped us but she was awesome too!
Ryan M — Google review
Very creative bar. It was worth to try. The earl grey caviar martini was very interesting. Tasted great. Came around 9pm and didn’t wait.
ABL — Google review
Atmosphere 8.5/10 Designed as a Monkey Express (train) bar. Obviously, they put in a lot of effort for the interior design - many authentic industrial train design elements. Great backbar. Can get a bit loud when busy. Drinks 7/10 Recommendation: Happy Cake Very creative menu design and large cocktail selection. The first part of the menu is around different elements (like glass, silk, gold, etc.) and drinks curated to represent those. The second part is a more traditional menu with some signature drinks. The cocktail taste did not convince me though - it felt like the presentation, which is clearly unique here, was prioritized over taste and balance of ingredients. Great for pictures, mediocre for taste experience. Nice coasters and glassware. Service 7/10 The team speaks English and takes time to explain the menu. Water is served on the spot. It might take some time to catch the team’s attention though… No snacks / warm towels or further service. Prices are average for Hong Kong. This bar is ranked #26 in Asia’s Best 50 Bars 2024. Even though it’s a fun bar, the ranking feels a bit high, considering the competition and high standards of other bars in Asia.
Anton S — Google review
Loud music and a packed bar late into the night, ideal if you like these vibes. The drinks are good but a bit on the sweeter side. I was expecting the wood to be spirit forward but it also had some sweetness that came through from the first sip.
Arnab S — Google review
Visited Quinary again after 6 years and I was surprised to see how much it changed. It was a Saturday night so they were really busy around 10pm, but they had an efficient queueing system with paper tickets. We didn’t want to wait long so we settled for a table outside since it was quite chilly. We noticed that the server handling the queue (Bridget) was so efficient and she was very attentive serving those seated outside throughout the night, we were actually very impressed! For our drinks, they were all just okay. We were quite overwhelmed with the options we could choose from. The server would explain the drinks upon serving, which we appreciated. I got the Quinary Sour, which was a savory drink with bonito flakes. Tasted very fishy but surprisingly it tasted good!
Jeanne S — Google review
A bit expensive, but it was worth to check our. We tried 3 cocktails and didn't regret any of them. We got lucky to get a table, but I'd seen people waiting outside. The vibe was cosy, music wasn't loud, but not enough lighting to read their menu. The staff seemed to be a bit busy to serve so many people, although they were polite and kind. They didn't bring water at first only when we asked.
Marina M — Google review
The interior was slightly cramped and the music very loud, lady who gave us seats was a bit impatient. The drinks were okay, I preferred the oolong tea cocktail over their signature earl grey cocktail. I also tried the truffle fries which were fine.
Karina K — Google review
Service was very good and the cocktails were inventive and were delivered with detailed explanations. Each item on the menu was interesting and told a story. Queuing system was very effective with a paper ticket format. We were seated in the front window space and unfortunately we had to leave early as so much cigarette smoke was coming through the cracks in the frame, which was bothering our group. I would definitely try to go back but get seated in an alternate place in the bar.
Trevor L — Google review

2COA

4.7
(596)
•
4.5
(22)
•
Mentioned on 
+15 other lists 
Cocktail bar
Bar
COA in Hong Kong is a laid-back bar that reflects the owner's love for Mexican flavors and ingredients. The 41-page menu is dedicated to agave spirits, showcasing the bar's commitment to this theme. The La Chinesca cocktail, named after a neighborhood in Mexicali, Mexico, combines jalapeno-infused tequila blanco with habanero spirit, tomato water, coriander, ginger, honey and lemon.
We went there on a Sunday evening at 5:45pm before the opening time of 6:00pm and there was already a queue to enter the bar. We were promptly seated at the bar upon opening which seems like a small and cosy bar space. I enjoyed the Smacked Cucumber cocktail that was not too strong for a tequila and mezcal based cocktail and there was a slight chilly aftertaste which I liked. COA specialises in agave based cocktails and have them in different styles from highball to negroni. Very innovative cocktails but suggest to go there early else it might be a longer wait to get a seat or table.
Arnab S — Google review
I arrived at weekday 5:30 PM in queue and got in around 6:15 PM with the last table. Coconut Milk Punch $128 is a must try. The flavors unfold beautifully, with distinct front middle back notes. Every ingredient is clear, smooth and well-balanced making the wait worthwhile. Donaji Mexicano $158 stood out with its smoky aroma and intriguing taste. Their straight tequila listed in the book not on the sheet menu. Bitter Melon Collins $128 had layered flavors too, but it just okay. My friend compared it to Thai green curry. Clover Club $128 was sweet and simple, I mean almost too light like non alcoholic drink. From past visits, I remember the Bloody Beef Maria and Smashed Cucumber tasting similar to some Thai salads. I like the taste of music and it was at comfortable volume making the air flow. Most staff were kind and warm, though two of them had a bit of attitude and occasionally rolled their eyes. I may return for Coconut Milk Punch and maybe a straight tequila. I think Coa is a solid bar, but slightly overrated.
UU L — Google review
We arrived around 5:25pm and the queue was already so long. Luckily we got a table for the first seating. The drinks were very unique, but in a good way. I tried the spicier drinks and I was surprised that I enjoyed them. Service was also very good, all of them were very attentive and friendly. Thank you also to Axel also for being very welcoming! Tip: go early or else they’ll tell you they are fully booked already! We went around 9pm the day before and they were fully booked already for the night.
Jeanne S — Google review
Probably the best bar in Hong Kong. Every single cocktail was outstanding and always with a complete difference flavor. You might need to queue before it opens to make sure that you get a seat in the first round. Alternatively they get your name and number and let you know approximately when there might be a table available. The staff was friendly and took the time to explain the drinks and offer some snacks.
Tomás F — Google review
Come early to sign up for an online waiting list, then head to dinner while waiting in queue! All the drinks are tequila based and were easy to drink, tasted complex and delicious. Some ingredients used were very creative and the execution of those drinks were impressive. We enjoyed everything we ordered which is often a bit or miss with cocktails. Service was great and it was a cozy bar to have a nice chat in.
Tung Y — Google review
My favorite bar in Hong Kong. E-queue managed through WhatsApp. Come here early and get into the queue! I saw the line starting to queue almost 1 hour before the bar opening time. The last order time is 23:00. Fantastic drinks, nice noisy crowd of people, great choice of music.
Evgeny — Google review
don’t think i need to say much about how popular this asia’s top bar is… if you want to come here just remember to queue up at least half an hour in advance to secure a bar table seat. my all time fav is definitely pepper smash! i love the complexity of the flavour and spicy kick which is irresistible. the coconut milk punch is also nice which is less strong and is a good first glass. coa is still one of my favorite bars and is living up to the the title as Asia’s best.
P T — Google review
Finding a speciality mezcal bar in Hong Kong wasn’t in my plans… amazing drinks, amazing people, amazing place… totally deserved to be issued in worlds 50 best bars.
Andres V — Google review
Wah Shin House, Shop A, LG/F Wah Shin House, 6-10 Shin Hing Street, Central, Hong Kong, 6-10 Shin Hing St, Central, Hong Kong•https://coa.com.hk/•+852 2813 5787•Tips and more reviews for COA

3The Aubrey

4.3
(257)
•
5.0
(360)
•
Mentioned on 
+14 other lists 
Japanese restaurant
Perched on the 25th floor of the Mandarin Oriental, The Aubrey is a unique Japanese izakaya that offers stunning panoramic views of Hong Kong. This stylish establishment boasts carefully curated design elements, including commissioned artwork and a playlist featuring groovy tunes to create an intimate atmosphere. Embracing Hong Kong's reputation as a hub for cultural exchange while honoring Japanism, The Aubrey celebrates both influences through its decor and culinary offerings.
The Aubrey in Hong Kong, located in the Mandarin Oriental, is an absolute gem! The interior is stunning, with a chic and intimate ambiance that feels perfect for a romantic date or celebrating something special. I recently visited, and the service was impeccable—attentive without being overbearing. The drinks were fantastic, and I’d highly recommend trying their Negroni—it was perfectly balanced. The whole experience felt luxurious but still warm and inviting. If you’re looking for a classy spot for cocktails or a memorable evening out, The Aubrey is a must-visit. Can’t wait to go back!
Zeno C — Google review
Atmosphere, decoration, location, drinks, food all world class. Thoroughly recommend this spot. It has deservedly become a place to be seen on Friday nights too. Well done to the team behind this, in a notoriously competitive F&B environment
Patrick C — Google review
The food was excellent at the Aubrey. Great taste, especially the snacks/starters were on point. Hamachi rolls and kerage chicken were the best. The mains were overall disappointing, the udon were a bit strange, slippery and eggy and milky. The pork however was super tasty and soft. We came while the best bar take over was on, and the drinks were a bot meh, being at the different bars, the drinks presented at the Aubrey were disappointing, mild not a good representation of the HK best bars. Finally, the sitting area was wonderful. Super chill, great interiors but freezing cold. Must also say that the cool interiors clash a bit with the izakaya idea. Was like being in an English gastro pub where served Japanese style pub food.
Andrea M — Google review
Atmosphere 8.5/10 Located inside the Mandarin Oriental hotel. Accordingly very high-end atmosphere and interior design elements. There are two different bar areas, with the main bar positioned in the middle of the room, creating a nice cocktail bar vibe. However, for the floor it is located on, the views are poor. The dress code is smart casual. Drinks 6/10 Recommendation: - The menu design is nice with a lot of signature cocktails, which all have some history behind them. However, the drinks did not taste good, nor did they have any interesting presentation orgarnish. Normal glassware is used. Nice coasters are provided. Service 5/10 This was a big disappointment for a place like the Mandarin Oriental. The bartender had no clue about their menu and couldn’t explain it or tell me where I can find food options. They serve water and complimentary snacks on the spot. But the price tag is just too high for the service level offered.
Anton S — Google review
Went to Aubrey for drinks on a cool, cloudy Saturday evening and felt instantly uplifted. We got a table by the window and got a great view of the harbour and the giant Ferris wheel. 5 stars for the following: - Service (our waiter recommended amazing drinks for us) - Comfort (the seats were ultra comfortable) - Bartender (the drinks were DELICIOUS) - Atmosphere (the VIBE was uplifting, classy, and calm) - Music (perfect volume and genre) - Interior decor (special mention for how classy it truly looks - not all hotel bars look this presentable in Hong Kong) Go only if you wish to have a guaranteed special time 😎
Natasha M — Google review
In Between the Line is hands down the best cocktail I’ve had in Hong Kong—and I’ve been to many bars. I’d love to return and try more from their menu. The atmosphere is classic and elegant, fitting for a bar in the Mandarin Oriental. However, service was a letdown. I visited solo at 2:30 PM when it wasn’t busy, but the bartenders were preoccupied with prep work, like carving ice, and weren’t very friendly. I expected some casual conversation but didn’t get much engagement. I’ll definitely revisit for the cocktails, but next time, I’ll go at a different time or day for a better experience.
Yi C — Google review
We went to our fair share of luxury bars and restaurants around Hong Kong, and The Aubrey became by far our favourite place to go. The setting is extremely nice, without being too noisy, and the different areas of the restaurant and bar means that you can experience relatively new atmospheres depending on where you are seated. The drinks are amazing, crafted with attention to details and are, to be fair, in the same price rage as any other bars in Hong Kong, which is remarkable. We tried the restaurant only once, and had the Premium Isakaya menu, which we are going to remember for a very long time. The seafood was exceptionally fresh, delicate and paired in a brilliant way. The waiters knew perfectly what they were doing and were able to tell us everything we wanted to know about the food coming to us. (Origin, type of seafood, order in which the chef thought it’d be best to eat in). We will come back as often as possible, and every time we do, it ends up being a very special evening. A special thank you to Leonardo and Marti who made us feel welcome and at home, and Tycoon and Andrew that displayed with brio their knowledge in their craft, and were able to make us drinks based on what they knew we’d love. Those wonderful people are what makes this place stand out from any other in Hong Kong.
Thibaut — Google review
Brilliant bento box style lunch. Really cool environment and great service. I look forward to coming back for dinner. The lunch is not too expensive if you go with the set menu.
Seb S — Google review
25/F, Mandarin Oriental, 5 Connaught Rd Central, Central, Hong Kong•https://www.mandarinoriental.com/en/hong-kong/victoria-harbour/d…•+852 2825 4001•Tips and more reviews for The Aubrey

4The Pontiac

$$$$affordable
Cocktail bar
Bar
The Pontiac, a beloved local bar, is marking its sixth year with an array of new and exciting drinks. Co-owner and head bartender Beckaly Franks has crafted unique concoctions like the Shells & Cigarettes, a sustainable twist on the classic Long Island made with ecoSPIRITS. The bar also offers a special #forgood pairing featuring low-waste cocktails and plant-based bites that contribute to water conservation, carbon emission reduction, and tree planting in Indonesia.
Great drinks and service at this bar. A decent amount of Americans in there. Very good cocktails and signature cocktails. Great prices, would recommend if in the area.
Winston H — Google review
Simply one of the best bars I’ve ever been to. The drinks are all creative and incredible, the bar tenders are fun and knowledgeable, and the soundtrack is flawless. Will be back tomorrow because it’s just that good.
Nicholas F — Google review
Great little spot with yummy cocktails at a reasonable price! Highly recommend the ‘River’! Bartenders were fun loving and engaging. Good old school rock music playing in the background.

Corbyn A — Google review

5ARGO

4.4
(243)

Mentioned on 
+14 other lists 
Restaurant
Bar
Bistro
Buffet restaurant
Lounge
ARGO, located at Four Seasons Hong Kong, has been recognized as the No.8 bar on Asia's 50 Best Bars list. The bar is led by beverage manager Federico Balzarini and head bartender Yvonne Chan, offering a unique cocktail menu called Here Today, Gone Tomorrow. This menu features six key ingredients such as coffee honey, rice, cacao, vanilla and apple which inspire traditional and reinvented cocktails.
ARGO is easily my favorite bar in Hong Kong. The atmosphere is beautiful and luxurious, and the bartenders are incredibly attentive, engaging in small talk and offering great drink recommendations. While the cocktails are unique and good, they’re not the absolute best in HK—but the vibe and service make up for it. Even with the high prices, I’d recommend it for anyone looking for a luxury cocktail experience.
Yi C — Google review
The food and drinks at this place are fantastic, and the atmosphere is super cool. The mirrored room is really fancy, and the service is great too. I highly recommend this place! However, if you’re not a hotel guest, you might want to reserve a table in advance to avoid any unnecessary waiting. Overall, it’s a great place to hang out and relax.
Shiwen D — Google review
We ate here for the lunch buffet, and I must say the food was quite disappointing. The staff were great; well trained and attentive, and the atmosphere was beautiful and comfortable as well, but the food quality was definitely lacking. The sirloin was the biggest disappointment, as it was overcooked, bland, and dry. However, the huge variety of well made desserts redeemed the other food items.
FT — Google review
The drinks are good, I had the Pineapple Jasmine it was refreshing and balance drinks. Highly recommend! Fiona was helping with our table, she is very nice and helpful. She gave us good recommendations based on our preferences. Very thoughtful throughout the whole time.
Wing L — Google review
I have visited a number of bars on 50 BEST World's Best Bars and Asia's 50 Best Bars list (October to December, 2024) whilst working in Hong Kong.  Argo comes in at number 58 in the world and 9 in Asia.  I am shocked that it is not way higher up.  Easily the best bar in Hong Kong.  I have travelled much of the world and this bar comes high on my list as somewhere I would recommend.  It didn't have the views like some bars but it was still intimate, dark and sexy.  I loved the decor.  You could still see some of the skyline.  The music was fabulous.  The staff were all pleasant and friendly.  I walked in as a solo female on a Friday evening, and luckily managed to grab a bar seat right by the window.  Service was outstanding.  I was looked after by a bartender named Andy.  I don't drink alcohol and Andy customized my complimentary welcome drink.  He was very good to check if I had any other dietary restrictions.  Real care for the guest.  You can page the menu for hours!  Some ingredients you would never expect in a cocktail.  I went with something different, the Kumquat & Hop Paloma cocktail.  I watched Andy make the drink.  What a cocktail, 0% ABV.  I had never tasted anything like it.  The hand cream was so unusual!  I had to rub the hand cream on my hands and then sip the cocktail.  It apparently enhanced the aroma.  Unique!  The cocktail was light, acidic and fragrant.  Simple, yet delicate.  I really appreciated that as a non-drinker, there were still options for me to choose from as many bars don't really cater for this, apart from a few soft drinks or juices.  They provide complimentary popcorn and olives which was perfect with the drink.  Alternatively, you can purchase something from the bar bites menu.  Lovely atmosphere.  Staff left you to enjoy your drink and relax, yet at the same time, they were attentive if you needed anything.  Believe me, if I could afford it, I would have sat for longer and had a few more cocktails.  It wasn't too pricey.  I was very happy with my drink, the service, music and atmosphere.  Lovely bar.  Some people were dressed up, others were casual.  Just look neat!  Trust me, I have visited several of the best bars in Hong Kong.  If you are short on time, put this at the top of your list.
Asme D — Google review
I’ve always been wanting to come visit this place and I finally did it. Shout out to the very welcoming Mr Federico Balzarini 🥂 a perfect ambiance and classy. And the main thing I came for gummy bears 🥰 cocktail is great. Staffs are friendly . Until my next visit 🫡 🥂

Definitely one of the best bars in HK. Great staff, efficient but personable. Have had a few drinks, this is the savory martini. (All martinis are savory, I think) served with a Ferran olive, which is always a treat. Housemade vermouth, bright gin

As you walk past the dozens of dishes you will notice that each one is well presented, and all made with fresh ingredients. 6DarkSide

4.3
(305)
•
Mentioned on 
+12 other lists 
Cocktail bar
DarkSide at Rosewood Hong Kong is a trendy cocktail bar that combines mixology and astronomy to create an innovative menu inspired by the phases of the moon. Ranked No. 40 on Asia's 50 Best Bars List, this Kowloon-side establishment offers a high-tech hologram video menu, a first in Hong Kong. The bar's interior boasts plush armchairs, bronze window casings, and a stunning ceiling installation featuring rotating hourglasses from Murano, Italy.
The service was very nice. The cocktails are good but I didn’t see the special menu this time. Hope next time I could visit around 8 when the live band performs.
Jenny, Y — Google review
Cute, sophisticated jazz bar located on the 2nd floor of the hotel. The interiors are fantastic and the show was very enjoyable. I am not sure why this bar appears as the 17th of the Best Asian Bars. The cocktails were overall not memorable, and also the ones that should have been savoury were actually quite sweet. They were not bad cocktails at all, just a bit generic in my opinion. I would go back for the atmosphere and if I find myself in Hong Kong dark side, but I feel other cocktails bar on the island to serve a better variety of drinks which have more complex depths. Drinks are 180HKD, regardless of size.
Andrea M — Google review
Had a really good time here. Service is great. Cocktails are all nice (we had 2 classics - blood&sand, brown derby- & 1 signature - the clock tower). Very creative menu selections, not much of a variety but definitely nice! The band playing during the night we visited was very talented as well. Overall, good vibes and really recommended for anyone visiting Tsim-tsa-tsui area to check this bar out.
Boon — Google review
Darkside has been ranked among the “Asia’s 50 Best Bars” for four consecutive years, and as a hotel bar, it consistently delivers top-notch service and ambiance. The cocktails lean a bit sweet, but the complimentary smoked olive snack is a standout—irresistibly delicious with a flavor that keeps you coming back for more. Prices start at HK$170, which is absolutely reasonable for a hotel-level experience. It’s a perfect spot to indulge in a luxurious treat every now and then—highly recommend!
Perri — Google review

Cocktail bar
Penicillin, located in Central, Hong Kong, is the city's first eco-conscious bar. The cocktail menu, titled "You Gotta Sustain it," features locally sourced or upcycled ingredients and pays homage to the flavors of Hong Kong.
Atmosphere 8/10 Cool vibe inside, feeling a bit like an apothecary basement. Relatively small bar, overall. Only a couple of bar counter seats and some table seating at the wall. Not recommended for bigger groups. Cool interior design elements. The back bar is replaced by medicine bottles. Drinks 6/10 Recommendation: One Penicillin, One Tree Small cocktail menu. Drinks have either a sustainability or medicine touch. Personally, I was not a big fan of the flavors they mix. One Penicillin One Tree is a milky/creamy cocktail. Anton S — Google review
Happened to walk past this bar while in the area and decided to grab a few drinks from here. The team is super chatty with guests which made my time spent here memorable. Love their concept of sustainability.
Elcorehaul — Google review
Used to be a great bar in Hong Kong and was once on the World’s 50 Best Bars list in 2021. However, over the years, the quality has dropped. The cocktails are just okay, with a somewhat flat taste, even though the ingredients are interesting—but the execution falls short. Blues N — Google review
Penicillin is more than just a cocktail bar—it’s a living, breathing ecosystem of creativity, sustainability, and deep cultural storytelling. Each drink is a chapter, and if you’re lucky enough to experience cocktails like “Third Culture Kid,” “Hot, Flat & Crowded,” “The Original,” and “One Pot Pan,” you’ll leave feeling like you’ve been on a journey far beyond the glass. “Third Culture Kid” is a revelation—a drink that speaks directly to those who live between worlds. The miso-buttered gin is silky and savory, giving the base a rich umami depth, while the sesame-pineapple applejack and green banana sherry add this layered sweetness that’s tropical yet restrained. The pandan-vermouth ties it all together with this whisper of nostalgia—herbal, slightly sweet, and unmistakably Southeast Asian. It’s fusion done with grace and intelligence—an identity in liquid form. “Hot, Flat & Crowded” is a full sensory experience. The mango-curd gin hits first—bright and tangy—before the salted burnt butter adds a decadent, slightly smoky note that lingers in the background. The grilled purple cabbage cream soda is the wild card: vegetal, fizzy, and oddly comforting. And then there’s the vitamin C—bringing zing, sharpness, and a wink to the drink’s commentary on modern excess and collapse. It’s chaotic, deliberate, and strangely beautiful—like the world it’s named after. “The Original” by Agung Prabowo is a masterstroke in minimal waste and maximum flavor. The waste shell vodka is clean and slightly briny, acting as a perfect canvas for the spiced cherry tomato, which brings a burst of acidity and warmth. The salted coconut cordial mellows everything out with a soft creaminess, and the clear lemon adds brightness without clouding the drink’s clarity—visually or flavor-wise. It’s sharp, clever, and respectful of every ingredient. You taste intention in every drop. “One Pot Pan” might be the most surprising of them all—a drink that shouldn’t work, but absolutely does. Pink guava tequila brings juicy tropical notes, while the vitamin B strawberry adds a unique sweetness and energy (literally). The charred chives sprig cordial introduces this unexpected green, smoky element that adds depth, and the clear makgeolli rounds it out with a subtle fermented note that gives the cocktail soul. It’s funky, vibrant, and incredibly layered—like a full meal disguised as a drink. Beyond the cocktails, the service at Penicillin is warm, knowledgeable, and genuine. The bartenders are storytellers, and the menu is a manifesto—one that speaks to a future of responsible, boundary-pushing mixology. In short, Penicillin isn’t just raising the bar—it is the bar. Five stars, no question. An absolute must-visit for anyone who cares about the art and ethics of drinking.
Jonathan H — Google review
We had a wonderful time at Penicillin! The vibes were chill, the drinks were creative and delicious, and the crew was warm and friendly. Penicillin champions sustainability and it's really cool to see how they manifest this into their bar concept. If you love a good drink (or a delicious kombucha) and you're in Hong Kong, please visit them!

Cocktail bar
Bar Leone, located in Central, Hong Kong, has quickly become a popular hotspot since its opening in May 2023. The brainchild of Lorenzo Antinori, previously of Argo and The American Bar at The Savoy, this bar offers a lively atmosphere reminiscent of traditional Roman bars. While reservations are not accepted and wait times can be long during peak hours, the classic cocktails with a twist and hearty bar food make it worth the wait.
Top notch cocktail experience - Deserves its place in the World’s Best Bars list. Cocktails are excellent, with great twists on some classics. There’s a small menu of delicious snacks. It’s walk ins only and very popular so it’s good to either arrive early, or go and add your name to the waitlist, explore the local area (lots of other cool places to check out) and they’ll WhatsApp you when your table’s free. We went around 17:45 and only waited for 30 minutes or so, which allowed us to explore the PMQ building on the next block.

Cocktail bar
Nestled in a hidden alley beneath the trendy H Code building in Central, Tell Camellia sets itself apart as more than just a typical cocktail bar. The menu features nine carefully crafted cocktails that skillfully blend tea and gin using modern techniques and state-of-the-art equipment. Each drink pays homage to the camellia Sinensis plant, the origin of all raw teas.
I recently visited Tell Camellia to try their innovative take on non-alcoholic tea cocktails. Knowing I'm a coffee lover, their drinks intrigued me. Tell Camellia is consistently recognized as one of the top bars in Hong Kong. In 2022, they were named to Asia's 50 Best Bars list, cementing their status as leaders in the industry. I decided to start with the "House Classics" flight, which included five mini cocktails ranging from  Ranch of Punch, Teapresso Martini, Tea Sea, Oolong Old Fashioned, Tea's Knees. The flavors were well-balanced and complex, showcasing how tea can be mixed in sophisticated cocktails. I was impressed at how the tea complemented rather than masked the coffee flavors. My favorite by far was the Teapresso Martini. Tell Camellia's staff are clearly passionate about tea. They were happy to discuss what types of tea were used in each drink and make recommendations based on my preferences. The relaxed and stylish atmosphere made it a great spot to linger over my drinks. I'll definitely be returning to explore more options on their menu, especially if they showcase tea in unexpected ways like the Teapresso Martini. It's the perfect place to discover new non-alcoholic beverage concepts and deserves its industry recognition.

The bar, for it is more of a bar than a restaurant, is done in a dark, stylish fashion. While intimate in size, the space is sophisticated, featuring large panoramic windows and a sleek bar counter, complemented by an extensive drinks list and well-curated small plates. Food: Our primary focus was, of course, the burger, though we also ordered the beef tartare to gain a broader perspective on their culinary abilities. The tartare was aesthetically pleasing, artfully arranged with croutons and roasted potatoes. However, the seasoning proved overpowering; the blend of spices, while undeniably bold (sharp, salty, and incredibly assertive), unfortunately overwhelmed the delicate flavor of the beef. The raw egg yolk provided some relief, tempering the intensity of the spices. A decent dish, ultimately, but lacking in the pure taste of the beef, with a somewhat uneven texture. The burger, touted as featuring Japanese Wagyu beef, lived up to expectations in presentation, at least. The patty was beautifully formed: thick, meaty, nestled between two perfectly browned buns. Unfortunately, the taste fell slightly short of its visual appeal. While the patty was juicy and possessed a rich, meaty flavor, enhanced by its pleasing fat content and char marks, there were occasional tougher segments that interrupted the overall culinary experience. The buns, however, proved disappointing. Dense and almost bread-like, rather than the light and airy brioche one would expect, their texture dominated the overall mouthfeel of the burger. The notable absence of any sauce felt like a stylistic choice, aiming perhaps for a pure, unadulterated beef flavour, but the combination ultimately lacked balance. Service: Service was excellent; the servers were friendly and engaging, making for a pleasant conversation about various Hong Kong establishments. However, clearing of the table was somewhat slow, and the small table size made the accumulating dirty dishes a minor annoyance. Conclusion: This is an excellent spot for drinks and the atmosphere of a trendy bar. While the burger, our primary motivation for visiting, didn't entirely meet expectations, it still maintained a high standard. A superb venue for a relaxed evening.

Maggie Choo's in Hong Kong, designed by renowned Ashley Sutton, offers a luxurious nightlife experience with a touch of old-world glamour from the Far East. The venue features live music from talented jazz and blues bands, cabaret entertainment, inventive cocktails, and late-night bites. Guests praise the courteous staff, fantastic cocktails, great atmosphere with live jazz on Fridays, and delicious food pairings. The bar's signature cocktails are creative spins on classics that receive high praise.
Maggie Choo's in Lan Kwai Fong (LKF), Hong Kong, is a visually stunning speakeasy-style bar that offers an immersive experience with its 1930s Shanghai-inspired theme. Known for its unique ambiance, the bar features antique décor, iron staircases, and vintage bank vault doors, creating an air of exclusivity and mystery. Atmosphere The venue exudes a glamorous vibe with dim lighting and plush seating, making it perfect for intimate gatherings or a stylish night out. The live jazz performances during weekdays add sophistication, while weekends bring lively cabaret acts and DJs that turn the bar into a vibrant party spot. Cocktails Maggie Choo's offers an inventive cocktail menu with Prohibition-era-inspired drinks. Favorites include: Sangria Highball Qi Pao: A fruity and refreshing choice. Maggie's Martini: A classic with a twist. The bar also offers a variety of bar snacks like crispy squid with yuzu mayo and smoked popcorn chicken with spicy sauce to complement the drinks. Highlights Entertainment: The cabaret performances are a highlight, featuring dancers in elaborate costumes, making the evenings feel theatrical and immersive. Service: Staff are attentive and knowledgeable about the menu, ensuring a seamless experience. Crowd: The bar attracts a mix of locals and expats, making it a cosmopolitan hotspot. Tips Reservations: It’s best to book a table in advance, especially on weekends, as the bar can get crowded. Dress Code: Smart casual is recommended to match the venue's upscale vibe. Verdict Maggie Choo's is a must-visit for those looking to experience a blend of elegance, creativity, and entertainment in Hong Kong’s nightlife scene. Whether you're in the mood for a quiet evening with jazz or a dynamic night of dancing, Maggie Choo's delivers on all fronts.

Permanently Closed
Cocktail bar
ROOM 309 is a hidden bar located within The Pottinger hotel in Hong Kong. To gain entry, visitors must request a keycard from the adjacent cocktail bar, The Envoy. Once inside, guests are treated to a unique experience with "invisible" drinks served from a menu that can only be read using a transparent panel against a dark surface. This speakeasy-style bar offers an exclusive and intriguing atmosphere for those looking to enjoy expertly crafted cocktails in a clandestine setting.

Popinjays at The Murray Hotel is an absolute gem that redefines luxury dining in Hong Kong. From the moment you step into the sleek private elevator ascending to the 26th floor, the anticipation builds for what promises to be an unforgettable experience. The panoramic 360-degree views of Central’s skyline and Victoria Peak from the wraparound terrace are nothing short of breathtaking, especially during sunset or under the glittering city lights at night 🌃 The culinary offerings are a masterclass in Italian craftsmanship. The menu, curated by Chef Alexandre, blends tradition with innovation—think Gran Crudo, a lavish seafood platter with oysters, langoustine, and Sicilian prawns, or the show-stopping Baked Alaska flambéed tableside for drama . The Pappardelle Al Brasato with slow-braised short rib is a must-try, showcasing rich, layered flavors that linger on the palate. For those seeking indulgence, the monthly Night Brunch is a highlight, offering unlimited premium dishes like charcoal-grilled lamb chops and free-flow Ruinart champagne, all set to live DJ beats performance . Service here is impeccable—attentive yet unobtrusive, with staff expertly guiding diners through the menu and wine pairings. The chic, modern ambiance, accentuated by art installations and golden accents, strikes a perfect balance between sophistication and relaxed elegance . Whether it’s a romantic dinner, a celebratory event in The Aviary private room, or cocktails under the stars, Popinjays delivers a flawless experience. A true standout in Hong Kong’s dining scene, it’s worth every star—and then some.

Restaurant
CALL ME AL is a newly-opened neighborhood bar that offers a convivial and laid-back ambiance, making it an ideal spot for a fun night out or a relaxing evening. The space features ample bar seating and high tables, complemented by an extensive wine and cocktail menu. The menu boasts comfort food at its best, including beef tartare, duck leg confit, ribeye, and decadent desserts. Guests can also enjoy delectable signature cocktails and perfectly crafted pasta dishes.

Cocktail bar
Bar De Luxe is a Japanese cocktail bar located in Central, within the premises of Attire House. It is led by renowned bartender Ueno Hidetsugu, owner of Tokyo's Bar High Five. The bar offers a spacious and relaxed ambiance with soothing music and lighting, making it an ideal spot for a weekend getaway. Guests can indulge in expertly crafted drinks such as the Japanese Yomogi Herb Liqueur, Plum Beauty, and Kirin Fuji Sanroku Whiskey.
Such a vibrant place to go to for drinks. Speak easy bar with amazing services. 50Hong Kong

Mentioned on 
3 lists 
Hong Kong, a vibrant city and special administrative region in China, is renowned for its diverse culinary scene. Since the 1960s, it has offered a wide array of dining options, from upscale Chinese and Western restaurants to street food stalls. The city's workforce growth led to caterers delivering lunches to offices and factories. Despite recent disruptions, the latest Michelin Guide recognized several outstanding restaurants in Hong Kong and Macau.
http://www.gov.hk/en/residents/•Tips and more reviews for Hong Kong
